div.p:
In trying to benefit the tribes living
under the Boers of the CashanMagaliesberg
mountains I performed twice
a journey of about 230300 300 miles
to the Eastward of Kolobong - Sechele
had become so obnoxious to the
Boers that though anxious to
accompany me in my journey
he dared not trust himself
among them - This did not arise
from the crime of
cattle stealing for a
charge of that whichthat crime,
is so common among
the Caffres, was never
madecharged against his
tribe or indeed against
any Bechuana tribe
The crime isIt is in fact unknown
in the country except
induring actual warfare.
His independaence
& love of the English
were his only faults - On my last
journey there of about 200 miles
he on parting with me at the
River Marikwe he gave me two
servants "to be" as he said
"his arms to serve me - " and
expressed regret that he could
not come himself - Suppose we
went North, would you come?
He commencedthen ^ and gave
me the story of Sebituane saving
his life and expatiated
on the far famed generosity of
that really great man - Theis
was the first time I had
thought of crossing the Desert
to Lake Ngami - The conduct
of the Boers in sending a letter
designed to produceprocure
my removal out
of the country and their well known
settled policy - became aswhich I have
already relateddescribed, became
more fully developed on
this than on any former
occasion - When I spoke
87 90
to Mr Hendrick Potgeiter of the danger of
hindering the gospel of Christ among
these poor savages he became
excessivelygreatly excited and called on one
of his followers
to answer me, He
threatened to
attack any tribe
that might recievereceive
a native teacher
but yet he yet promised
to use his influence to prevent those
under him from throwing obstacles
in our way - I could however
percieveperceive plainly that nothing more
could be done in that direction
so I commenced getting all
the information I could about
the Desert with the intention
toof crossing it if possible: Sekomi
the chief of the Bamangwato
was acquainted with had a pathroute which he kept
carefully to himself because
the Lake country abounded
in Ivory and he drew large
quantities of itthence periodically
at but small cost to himself -
Sechele who valued highly
everything European and
was always quite wide
fully alive awake to his own interest
was naturally anxious to get
a share of that inviting field -
He was most anxious to
visit Sebituane too, partly
perhaps from a wish to
shewshow off his new acquirements
but chiefly I believe from
having very exalted ideas
of the benefits he would
derive from the liberality of
that renowned chieftain
88 91
In age ^ and family Sechele is the elder ^ and superior of
Sekomi, andfor when the original
tribe broke up into Bamangwato
Bangwaketse &
Bakuena The Bakuena
returned the hereditary chieftainship
So their chief Sechele possesses
certain advantages over Sekomi
the chief of the Bamangwato -
If the two were travelling [or hunting 33 Coult.Coulter together
Sechele would take by
right the heads of the game
shot by Sekomi - There are
several ^ vestiges ^ besides of very ancient partitions
and lordships ^ of tribes - The elder brother of
Sechele's father became
blind and he gave
over the chieftainship
to Sechele's father - The
descendantsdescendents of this
man pay no tribute
to Sechele and when
the ^ latter addresses the head
of the family he
calls him Kosi
or chief - though
Sechele in every other respect is
the ruler. The other tribes for
instance ^ wontwill not begin to eat the early
pumpkins of a new crop
untilluntil they hear that the
Bahurutse have "bitten it - " and
there is a public ceremony
on the occasion - the son of
the chief being the first to taste
of the new harvest - Sechele
by my advice sent men to
Sekomi asking leave ^ for me to
pass along his path for me
accompanying the request
with the present of an ox -
Sekomi's mother who
possesses great influence
over him refused because
she had not been acknowledged
This produced a fresh message
and the most honourable
man ^ in the Bakwena tribe next to Sechele was
sent with an ox ^ each for both
himself Sekomi & his mother
This too was met by refusal - It
It was said "the MatibeleMatebele the mortal enemies of
the Bechuanas are in the Ddirection of the
Lake and should they kill him we shall
inincur great blame among all the
white men"

89 92
The exact position of the Lake
had all along ^ for half a century at least been correctly
pointed out by the natives
who had visited it
when rains were
more copious in
the Desert - and many attempts
had been made to reach it by
passing through the desert
in the direction indicated,
but it was found impossible
even for Griquas who having
some Bushman blood in
them may be supposed more
capable of enduring thirst than
Europeans - It was clear then
that our only chance of success
was by going round instead
of through the Desert - The best
time for the attempt would have
been about the end of the rainy
season in March or April
for then we should have been
likely to meet with pools of rain
water which always dry up
during ourthe rainless winter -
But having communicated
my intention to an African
traveller Colonel Steele then Aid-de
campAide-de-camp to the Marquis of Tweedale
at Madras he made it known
to ourtwo other two gentlemen friends whomse we
friendship we had made byduring their African travel viz.videlicet
Captain Vardon and Mr
OswelOswell - All of these gentlemen
were so enamoured with African
hunting and African huntingdiscovery
that I am sure the two former
envied the latter his fortune
90 5- 93
in being able to leave India to undertake
afresh the pleasures & pains of
desert life, I believe Mr O.Oswell came
from his high position at a very considerable pecuniary
sacrifice, and with no other
end in view but to extend
the boundaries of geographical
knowledge - When he Before I
knew of his coming which he
did by the overland passage
I had arranged that the payment
for guides furnished by Sechele
should be the loan of my
waggon to bring out whatever
ivory he might obtain from
the chief at the Lake - And I
adhered to the bargain though
when at last Mr OswelOswell did
come (bringing Mr Murray with him)
he undertook to defray the
entire expenses of ^ the guides, and
as he had already generously
presented a good new waggon
to my little boy - though that
which I actually took to the Lake
to perform SechelesSechele's work ^ was ruined by the workjourney yet
it is plain that the whole of
the expenses of the discovery
of Lake Ngami were borne
by the purse of this gentleman -

Sechele himself would have
come but fearing that the much
talked of assault of the Boers
might take place during our
absence and blame be attached
91 94
to me for taking him away, I
dissuaded him against it by
saying that he knew Mr OswelOswell
"waswould be as determined as himself
to get through the Desert - " Their objects
were totally different however -

Wilkes While waiting at Kolobong for
the company of Mr OswelOswell I may
give some noticesaccount ^ of the great
Kalahari desert that the reader
may understand exactlyin some degree the
nature of the difficulties we had
to encounter -

The space betweenfrom the Orange
River in the South - LatLatitude 29 - to
Lake Ngami in the North, and
from about 24˚ East LongLongitude
to near to the West coast has been
called a Desert simply because
it contains no surrounding water
and very little ^ water in wells - It
is by no means destitute of
vegetation and inhabitants
for it is covered with grass
and a great variety of
creeping plants - Besides
grass we havethere are large patches
of bushes and even trees
Prodigious herds of It is
remarkably flat but intersectedc
in different parts by the
beds of ancient rivers, and
prodigious herds of certain
antelopes which require little
or no water roam over
92 95
the tackless plains - The inhabitants
Bushmen and Bakalahari
prey on the game and on
the countless numbers of
a small Rodentiaea and small
species of the feline race which
subsist on these - In general
the soil is light coloured
silicious silicasoft sand - nearly
pure silica - The beds of the ancient river havecontain much alluvial
soil in their bottoms and
as that is baked hard by
the burning sand, rain-
water stands in pools in
some of these for somemanyseveral
months annually - in the year

The quantity of grass which
grows on this remarkable
region is astonishing to
gentlemen even ^ to those who are
familiar with India - It usually
grows in tufts with bare
spaces between - or the latter
are occupied by creeping
plants which having
their roots buried far
beneath the soil feel little
the effects of the scorching
sun - The number of these
which have tuberous roots
is very great asand their structure if it were
is intended to supply nutriment
and moisture when during
the long droughts they can
93 96
be obtained nowhere else - Here
we have ^ an examples of a plant
not generally tuber bearing
becoming so in circumstances
where that appendage is
necessary to act as a
reservoir for preserving its
life - In Angola I shall refer to
a species of grape bearing
vine which is so furnished
in and for the same purpose
that at present noticed is
one of the cucurbitaceae which
bears a small scarlet coloured
eatable cucumber - Another
plant named "Leroshua" is a
blessing to the inhabitants
of the desert - We see a
small plant with linear
leaves and stalk not thicker
than a crowscrow's quill & on digging down
a foot or 18 inches and you
there are we come to a tuber often as large
as ^ the head of a young childs head - When
the rind is removed, we find
it to be a mass of cellular tissue
each filled with fluid much
like a pleasant sappy turnip
and it is, from its depth
beneath the soil, generally
deliciously cool and
refreshing - Another kind
named mokuri is seen in
other parts of the country
where long continued hot
94 97
^ heat parches the soil - The plant
is a herbaceous creeper and
deposits a number of tubers
some as large as a mansman's
head at spots in a circle
a yard or if itmore horizontally
from the stem - The natives
percussstrike the ground on the
circumference of the
circle with stones till by
hearing a different sound
they know the water bearing
tuber to be beneath - They
then dig down a foot or
so and find it -

Robinson But Both the most surprising
plant of the desert is the
bitter water melon - In
years when more than the
the usual quantity of rain
falls, prodigious tracts
of the country are literally
covered with them - these melons This
was the case annually
when the fall of rain was
greater than it is now and the Bakuena
sent trading parties every
year to the Lake - It has
happened again as the cycle
of 10½1/2 or eleven years occurred,
which for the last three
such periods has come
round with an extraordinary
wet season - Then animals
95 98 10
of every sort and name,
including man, rejoice in
the rich supply - The Elephant
true Lord of the Forest revels
in them and so doesdo the different
species of RhinocrosRhinoceros - although
so diverse in their naturally
choice of pasture -

The different kinds of
antelopes feed on them
with equal avidity and
lions hyaenas jackallsjackals
and mice all seem to
know and appreciate the
common blessing -

96 99
The human inhabitants ^ of this tract of Country consist
of Bushmen and Bakalahari - The
former probably the aboriginales of
the Southern position of the continent
the latter the remnants of the first
emigration of Bechuanas - The
Bushmen live in the desert from
choice, the Bakalahari from
compulsion, & both possessing an
intense insatiable love of liberty - The
Bushmen are the only real nomades
in the country - they never
cultivate the soul nor rear any
domestic animal save wretched
dogs - They are so intimately
acquainted with the habits of
the game that they follow them
in their migrations and prey
upon them from place to
place & ^ thus provieng as naturalcompletely
a check upon ^ their inordinate increase
as the other carnivori are - Their
The chief subsistence ^ of the Bushmen is the meat of
game but that is eked out by
what the women collect of
roots and beans and fruits of
the desert - Those who live oninhabit
the hot sandy plains of the desert
possess generally thin wiry forms
capable of ^ undergoing great exertion and
of enduring severe privations - Many
are of low though not dwarfish -
stature - The specimens brought
97 100
to Europe have been selected onlike
costermonger's dogs ^ on account of their extreme ugliness
Consequently, English and their ideas of the whole ^ tribe are
formed in the same way as
if the ugliest specimens of the
English were exhibited in
AmericaAfrica as characteristic of
the ^ entire British nation - tThat they are like
baboons is a parallel truthin some degree truth
just as with that these and other
simiae ^ are in some things are
frightfully human -

The Bakalahari are traditionally
reported to be ^ the oldest of the Bechuana tribes
and they possessed enormous herds of the large horned cattle
mentioned by Bruce beforeuntil
they were despoiled of them and
driven into the desert by a fresh
migration of the their own nation
98 101 13
Living ever since on the same
plains with the Bushmen subject
to the same climatical influences ^ of climate
enduring the same thirst and
subsisting on the same food
for centuries they seem to
supply a standing proof that
(Qu.Query this - I do
not quite catch
the meaning) locality does not aloneis not always sufficient of itself to account
for difference in races - The
Bakalahari retain in undying
vigour the Bechauana love for
agriculture and domestic animals
They hoe their gardens annually
though often all they can aihope
for is thea supply of melons &
pumpkins, and they carefully
rear small herds of goats
though I have seen them lift
water for them out of small
wells with a bit of ostrich egg
shell or by spoonfuls -
They generally attach themselves
to influential men in the
different Bechuana tribes living
a adjacent to their desert home
in order to obtain supplies of
spears, knives tobacco and
dogs in lieuexchange for the skins
of the animals they may kill -
These are small carnivoraei of
the feline species - Two species
of JackallJackal - the dark and
the golden JackallJackal - the former
QyQuery --- Motlose is the warmest fur
the country yields - the latter
99 102
or phukuye is very handsome
when made into the skin mantle
called Kaross - Then follows
next in value the tsipa a
small ocelot - The Tuane or
Lynx - The wild cat, the spotted
cat - and other small animals
Great numbers of Puti and
puruhuru skins are got too
besides ^ those of Lion'slions leopards &
panthers & hyaenas - During the
time I was in the Bechuana
country between 20 000 and
30 000 skins were made
up into Karosses - part of
them were worn by the
inhabitants and part sold
to the traders - the latter I believe
often find their way to
China - The Bakwains brought
tobacco from the Eastern tribes
then purchased skins with it
from the Bakalahari - tanned
them and sewed
them into Karosses
then went south
to purchase
heifer calves
with them - Cows
being the [highest
form of riches
known, as I have
often noticed
when they asked
"if Victoria had
many cows" The compact they enter into is
mutually beneficial but injustice
and wrong are often perpetrated
by one tribe going among the
Bakalahari of another and
compelling them to deliver up
the skins which they may be
keeping for their friends - They
are a third race and in bodily
development often resemble
the Australlians - They have thin
legs and arms and large
100 103 15
protruding abdomens caused
by the coarse indigestible food
they eat - Their children's eyes
lack lustre, I never saw them
X at play - A few Bechuana may
go into a village and domineer
over the whole with impunity
but when these same adventurers
meet the Bushmen they are fain
to change their manners to fawning
sycophancy - They know ^ that if
the request for tobacco is
refused these free sons of the
desert may settle the point
whether it is possessed or
not by a poisoned arrow -
Carp # The dread of visits from Bechuanas
of strange tribes causes the
Bakalahari to choose their
residences far from water -
and they not infrequently
hide their supplies by filling
the pits with sand and
making a fire over the
spot - When they wish to
draw water for use the
women come with twenty or
thirty of their water vessels in
a a bag onor net on their
backs - And these ^ water vessels consist
of ostrich egg shells with a
hole in the end of each such
as would admit onesone's finger
The women They tie a bunch of grass to
101 104
one end of a reed about two
feet long - dig a hole as deep
as the arm will reach and
insert the reed - then ram down
the wet sand firmly - Applying
the fmouth to the free end
of the reed they form a
vacuum in the grass - the
water collects and in a
short time reaches the mouth -
An egg shell is placed along
side the reed below the
mouth of the sucker - A straw
guides the water into the
hole of the vessel as she
draws mouthful after
mouthful from below - Her
whole stock of water hasis thus
passed through her mouth
as ^ through a pump and when
taken home is carefully
buried - I have come into
villages where had we acted
a domineering part and
rum^maged every hut, I should

but by sitting down quietly
and waiting with patience
they ^ villages were allowedled to form
a favourable opinion of us
and a woman would
bring out a shellful of the
precious fluid from I know

is by no mean a useless
tract of country, Besides
supporting multitudes of
both small and large animals
toit sends something to the

many a fugitive tribe - to
The BalahariBakalahari first and to

not a drop of water could

Bakuena perished too
Their old men who could have
